title: Somehow they pulled this off
content: I consider myself a big comic book marvel fan. My favorite films from the franchise so far
sum: are Cap. American: Winter Soldier and Thor: Ragnarok. As this movie was directed by the same guys as Winter Soldier and Civil War
column7: I went into this movie with sky-high expectations. I am gonna keep this brief: Avengers: Infinity War blew me away! If I should mention just one thing that really amazed me was the character of Thanos. He is so well developed and makes for a super interesting and complex villain. As an audience
column8: we are actually capable of sympathizing with a guy
column9: who wants to kill off half of the universe. It's not about power or dominance. It's about preserving life in a Universe with finite resources - a goal with leads him (and the avengers) into several interesting moral dilemmas. I agree with the other reviews here. This movie is such a beautiful calamity of 10 years of the best superhero entertainment there is. Thinking about it
column10: I can't really grasp how the director pulled this off. So many well developed characters from different story lines are working together in a true cinematic symphony. I give this movie my highest recommendations. It's a must-see for anyone with just a remote interest in the franchise.

title: Unlike anything ever done in the history of cinema
content: This movie is the beginning of the culmination of Marvel's masterfully woven cinematic universe. Beginning back in 2008 with iron man
sum: we are finally seeing the results of all the movies have been pointing to; and it did not disappoint. Thanos is a complex villain
column7: with deeper and more interesting desires than just "world domination." The dilemmas all the characters face in this movie (both the heroes and the villains) are truly thought provoking and leave you on the edge of your seat. No other set of movies has beeen so involved
column9: and encompassed so many story lines/characters and previous movies. The sheer amount of star power alone in this film is insane; and they do a masterful job of weaving all these unique and various characters into a common storyline.

title: This movie will blow your mind and break your heart - and make you desperate to go back for more. Brave
writer: brilliant and better than it has any right to be.
content: 25 April 2018
column7: Marvel has earned itself the benefit of the doubt. The studio has consistently delivered smart
column9: brave films that both embrace and transcend their comic-book origins. The 18 blockbuster movies produced since Iron Man first blasted off into the stratosphere in 2008 have not only reinvented superhero films as a genre - they've helped to legitimise it. Indeed
column10: Marvel's two most recent films - Thor: Ragnarok and Black Panther - have received the kind of accolades usually reserved for edgy arthouse flicks. And yet
column11: it's perfectly reasonable to be apprehensive about Avengers: Infinity War. This is a blockbuster film that's been ten years in the making
column12: its plot hinted at and scattered throughout 18 other movies. It features 30 or so characters
column13: each with their own complex backstories and motivations. And all of them are coming together in a bid to stop a giant purple alien dude from destroying the universe. It sounds ridiculous
column14: and feels impossible. But that's precisely what makes the final product such a monumental achievement. Masterfully directed by Anthony and Joe Russo
column16: brainy filmmaking at its very best: the kind that will lift your spirits
column17: blow your mind and shatter your soul - occasionally in the same scene. It demonstrates on an epic scale what Marvel has known all along: that special effects and tightly choreographed action are there to serve the story. For all its blockbuster spectacle (and there's almost too much of that)
column18: the film works because it's anchored by the heart
column19: humour and humanity of its characters.The film's basic plot is simple: Thanos (played via motion-capture by Josh Brolin)
column20: intergalactic purveyor of death and destruction
column21: has long been on the hunt for the six Infinity Stones that will give him complete control over the elemental building blocks of the universe. He dispatches his acolytes to Earth to retrieve the Time Stone
column22: currently in the possession of Dr. Stephen Strange (Benedict Cumberbatch)
column23: and carve the Mind Stone out of the forehead of Vision (Paul Bettany). It's a literal existential threat so terrifying that all the heroes we've come to know and love - from the Avengers to the Guardians of the Galaxy - must put aside their differences and unite against a common foe. From the outset
column24: it's immediately clear that neither the film's directors nor screenwriters (Christopher Markus and Stephen McFeely) are interested in playing it safe. Most other superhero films are bled of high stakes - the hero in the title might suffer untold trauma
column25: but it's a super-safe bet that he or she will make it to the end alive. There's no such guarantee here. Within the first ten minutes
column26: we are confronted with the dark
column27: twisted depths to which Thanos and his acolytes in the Black Order will sink in order to achieve their goals. Death
column28: as well as genuine loss and sacrifice
column29: is intrinsic to the narrative drumbeat that drives Infinity War ever forward
column30: and the film is all the better for it. That's not to say the movie is a morbid and depressing experience. What's so impressive about Infinity War is how it expertly juggles its constantly shifting tones and moods. When it's funny (and it very often is)
column32: truly funny. The film finds maximum joy in flinging characters together with merry abandon
column33: mixing and matching ones you'd never have expected to share scenes or trade banter. Peter Quill (Chris Pratt) is floored by Thor's (Chris Hemsworth) godly muscles. Bruce Banner (Mark Ruffalo) is charmed by the wit and intelligence of Shuri (Letitia Wright). And it'd be impossible to not be utterly delighted by Peter Dinklage's inspired cameo. It's a blithely tongue-in-cheek sensibility shared by Marvel's best comic books
column34: which understand that humour can make you care when it really counts.And
column36: does Infinity War make it count. There are many heartbreakingly human moments threaded throughout the film: from the charming surrogate father-son dynamic shared by Tony Stark (Robert Downey Jr) and Peter Parker (Tom Holland)
column37: to the undeniable love that ties Vision and Wanda Maximoff (Elizabeth Olsen) together. In many ways
column38: the film stands as a testament to the human capacity not just to love
column39: but to love fiercely and beyond all logic. It's right there when the unfailingly noble Steve Rogers (Chris Evans) declares
column41: even when giving up one could save billions. There's even a chilling echo of it in Thanos himself. A lesser film would have turned Thanos into a one-dimensional villain
column42: much the way he's all monster and maniac in the comic books. In Infinity War
column44: Thanos' end goal is surprisingly relevant when it comes to thinking and talking about the staggeringly overpopulated world in which we live today. There is
column46: method to Thanos' madness. It makes the tragic twists and turns in his relationships with his estranged adopted daughters
column48: all the more unsettling. For the most part
column51: to the many heroes who have been assembled for the film. The Russo brothers displayed great skill at interweaving multiple perspectives and character trajectories in Captain America: Civil War
column52: and they do so again here
column53: with twice as many characters. Even the most minor of supporting players
column54: like Don Cheadle's James Rhodes/War Machine
column55: are given story beats that land. It helps that Marvel has always taken care to cast genuinely good actors in roles that might otherwise come off as silly and slight. Even so
column56: there are a few standouts amongst this enormous and enormously talented cast. Emotionally speaking
column57: this is Downey's film. He plays every note of Tony's reluctant courage and bone-deep trauma
column58: as he embarks on what he's convinced is a suicide mission. He's ably matched by Cumberbatch
column59: who finds vulnerability even in his character's most cunning and calculative move. Hemsworth
column61: is given free rein to import the big-hearted comedic swagger of Thor: Ragnarok into this film - while also layering it with a deeply-felt
column62: jagged grief for the losses he has suffered at the hands of Thanos and the universe.In a film with so many moving parts
column63: some elements don't work quite as well. A couple of characters that you might have expected to be right at the forefront - including an original Avenger or two - fade into the background. The film tumbles from dizzying fight scene to dizzying fight scene
column64: and while most of them are fantastically choreographed
column65: there are some purely dumb moments that literally revolve around attempts to prevent Thanos from clenching his fist. In effect
column66: this is a superhero mêlée that's part over-the-top and part overkill
column67: and might prove too much for those who don't already care for this franchise and the characters in it.Minor quibbles aside
column69: Infinity War is yet another step in the right direction for Marvel. It continues the studio's tradition of placing a premium on rich
column70: complex storytelling that respects both its characters and its audiences. But it also refuses to make things easy for itself. The film ends even more bravely than it began
column71: with a final ten minutes that will haunt and horrify you in equal measure. It's a stroke of bold
column72: brilliant genius - a narrative risk so audacious that you'll want to follow Marvel wherever it goes next.

title: A Summer Film That IS Even Better Than The Hype
content: Summer movies often hype themselves as spectacular events not to be missed and their ad campaigns use words like "epic"
column7: and "smash" as ways to build the hype to increase advanced box office sales.

score: The summer 2018 film season kicks off in a big way with "Avengers: Infinity War" and it is the rare summer film that exceeds is lofty expectations and delivers a crowning achievement for the Marvel Cinematic Universe.
When Thanos (Josh Brolin)
title: embarks on a deadly campaign to find and possess the Infinity Stones
writer: he leaves a path of death and destruction in his path. When his pursuit leading him to Earth
content: and Doctor Strange (Benedict Cumberbatch)
sum: who enlist a reluctant Tony Stark (Robert Downey Jr.)
column7: to the cause just as the minions of Thanos arrive.

score: With The Avengers fractured and scattered following the events of "Captain America: Civil War" the teams find themselves dealing with the threat in various groups as fate steps in to divide many key members of the team. This allows for a great entry by the Guardians of the Galaxy and allows the film to take a very enjoyable path. Essentially the movie weaves separate storylines into one cohesive and very satisfying epic. You have a story with the Guardians as well as one with many of the key Avengers
title: as well as others with characters old and new. As such it is like a Guardians
date: and Marvel film all rolled into one and each one supports the other very well yet has the charm and identity you would expect. While the tone is very dark as you would expect with literally half of the known universe facing destruction
content: there is also some solid humor in the film that never once undermines the story or pacing.

score: Naturally the effects are stunning as you would expect as Marvel has put a significant amount of money into the film and it shows in every eye-popping action sequence.
What really impressed me the most was that the Russo Brothers never let the FX of the film overshadow the characters and with a very large cast
title: it was nice to see everyone got their moment and you did not see members of the cast trying to one up each other.

score: There are some real surprise moments along the way and the action is easily the best of any Marvel film to date. Many fans had expressed disappointment with "Avengers: Age of Ultron" for me this film is significantly better than the prior film and is everything that a Marvel fan would want in a film.

I was also surprised by how well Thanos was portrayed as while you hopefully will not agree with his deductions and methods; you could actually understand his motivations and it help him transcend from the usual megalomaniacs which are so common in films of his type. I am really looking forward to seeing what comes next and make sure you stay through the credits for a bonus scene.
Believe the hype
title: "Avengers: Infinity War" is an epic not to be missed and is an example of what a summer event film should be.

score: 5 stars out of 5

title: Excellent Film
content: I was amazed to see so many negative reviews; so many people are impossible to please. This movie was 2 1/2 hours long
sum: but I could have sat there another 2 1/2 hours and not noticed. Thoroughly entertaining

title: Breathtaking
content: Infinity War does a brilliant job by seamlessly combining the last few films together. It picks up where Ragnarok left off on the space shuttle with Thor
column7: Hulk and all the remaining Asgardians. It opens with a distress call as Thanos and his Dark Order have slaughtered most of passengers including some of the remaining Asgardians. He interrogates Thor and beats Hulk so bad he is too scared to ever turn green again. A defeated Hulk/Bruce Banner is then transported to Doctor Strange's Sanctum Sanctorum so he can warn him of Thanos' arrival. It is down to Doctor Strange
column9: Tony Stark and Spider Man to prevent Thanos' evil minions from destroying New York and taking the time stone. It's a thrilling action sequence that introduces Starks cool new nano-bot armour that creates its own swords and shields. Thanos has been teased since 2012 and the wait has paid off here as he is by far one of the best villains. The story is more about him achieving his goals which is refreshing to see as the villains are normally sidelined in these films. He is so determined to get all six gems
column10: each gem making him stronger. The Avengers and Guardians have to race against time to stop him from finding all six. One sequence on his home planet 'Titan' is worth mentioning and like most of the film
column11: it is breathtaking and tense. His crew (Dark Order) also seem unbeatable as they battle the rest of the Avengers in Wakanda with their alien army which also proves difficult. Thanos gets some interesting backstory
column12: it would have been even better if the menacing Dark Order got some backstory themselves as we never really understand them or their motivations.Even though it enters familiar ground
column13: it is often done differently and most of the time it's unpredictable. It's full of surprises and twists which will leave you exhausted by the end. Although Infinity War feels over stuffed with characters and storylines
column14: the Russo Brothers do an exceptional job by giving each character enough to do. Its great to see some focus on characters like Gamora and Thor as previous films have kept it prominently on characters Iron Man
column15: Hulk and Captain America. That's not to say they don't get anything to do because they do
column16: it's just not as much as usual. This entry really does require you to see all of the ones before it as it can become confusing. They often call back to previous events and storylines
column17: so it's a better experience if you are familiar with all of them. There are also so many fun references like Rocket Racoon's need for artificial limbs
column18: Thor's new haircut and Drax's constant quips. There are too many visual effects shots which could have been avoided using practical effects. The CGI shots don't look bad
column19: but sometimes they can be distracting. However it's a technique that is quicker than any other
column20: and with studio films of this scale that's just a small price to pay. The action scenes are so well directed accompanied by a music score by Alan Silvestri who always adds that extra level of excitement to them. It is a relief to say Infinity War runs well over 2 hours 30 minutes which is the longest Marvel film. There is no point saying its "baggy" or "overlong" as fans of the franchise will greatly appreciate this and with so much going on the runtime is justified.

score: 'Avengers Infinity War' is first and foremost a superhero movie that embraces the genre and exploits it to the fullest. A film with great ambitions that is capable of surpassing itself
title: resulting in one of the best films in the studio and in the genre itself.
The Best Marvel Movie
content: 10 Years of Build Up wasn't wasted on this Movie. Infinity War is one of the greatest movies of all time because of how carefully they set everything else up. Stellar character growth and an incredible story make this stand out amongst the rest of Marvel. Thanos is one of the Greatest Movie Villains of all time due to the handling of his character. Everything from the beginning filled with dread of what's To come to the ending where they fulfilled their promise of dread was done perfectly. Infinity War is one of the best action movies ever made.
